info.game_comments:
Ben Bishop game 1.
Champion Update #1: Frank Spangenberg.

(1, 1).clue: In the Middle Ages this city's main street, Via del Corso, was used as a horse-racing course

(3, 1).clue: Attention, fashion victims: shoes that are too tight may lead to ingrown these

(4, 1).clue: Debbie Reynolds & Kathy Bates both played this "unsinkable" woman on film

(5, 1).clue: This cold-induced condition can progress dangerously from tingling to gangrene

(6, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew is served a potent potable from a special glassware at the International Butler Academy, the Netherlands.)  Vintage port served at a dinner party should stand upright for 24 hours before uncorking, & it's imperative that once service starts, this container doesn't touch the table

(1, 2).clue: In 1381 Wat Tyler led a failed peasants' revolt in England protesting this tax on voters

(3, 2).clue: Golfer's elbow is similar to this other "sporty" affliction, but golfer's elbow occurs on the inside of the joint

(4, 2).clue: In December 2006 thousands of fans & friends gathered at the Apollo Theater to pay their final respects to him

(5, 2).clue: Hirsute arachnid of the Theraphosidae family

(6, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew sits at a place setting at the International Butler Academy, the Netherlands.)  Spoon handles for this course should all face to the right, forks to the left, & they are always positioned above the place setting

(1, 3).clue: According to legend, a Norseman named Rurik settled in Novgorod in 862 & founded this country

(3, 3).clue: If you have a deep cut or dirty wound, get a booster shot for this if you haven't had one in the last 5 yrs.

(4, 3).clue: His 1998 techno-thriller "Digital Fortress" focuses on NSA cryptographer Susan Fletcher

(5, 3).clue: A synonym for "ludicrous parody", it's also the bawdy type of entertainment seen here

(6, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew keeps the shirt on his back at the International Butler Academy, the Netherlands.)  The long staple or the long fiber of the cotton produced in this African country is the reason why the International Butler Academy considers it the best

(1, 4).clue: Trial by fire & by water were part of this medieval procedure, now meaning any painful experience to be endured

(3, 4).clue: Mozart wrote about eating pork cutlets before his final illness, which led to a 2001 theory that he died of this

(5, 4).clue: A branch of science, or a sympathetic rapport between 2 people

(6, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew eats expensive fish eggs at the International Butler Academy, the Netherlands.)  The academy teaches the proper serving of caviar--always use a nonmetallic spoon, perhaps one made of this material, from the interior of mollusks

(1, 5).clue: In 1096 this French monk & a knight known as Walter the Penniless set out for the holy land in the People's Crusade

(3, 5).clue: Swelling of the ankles may be an indication of DVT, or deep-vein this

(6, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew watches a butler fold napkins at the International Butler Academy, the Netherlands.) Good butlers have at their disposal an arsenal of different napkin folds; this one involving several pleats has the same name as an Oscar Wilde play

(1, 1).clue: Before Europeans named Mt. Cook in this country, the Maori called it Aorangi, or "cloud piercer"

(2, 1).clue: Sam & Diane, bar-toilers both / Sometimes, thou wishest to travel where ev'ryone knows thy name

(4, 1).clue: In 1967 this future labor leader became an electrician at the shipyards in Gdansk

(6, 1).clue: A CONTROL secret agent is good at operating these weapons that are precisely guided to a target

(1, 2).clue: Soc Trang & Can Tho are in the south of this Asian nation

(2, 2).clue: Verily, Ross & Rachel walked love's true path but yea! / 'Twas a perilous road for Joey / Filled with cancellation

(4, 2).clue: In August 1981 more than 11,000 of these federal workers were fired for participating in an illegal strike

(6, 2).clue: Dynastic "Everyday People" singing group that subdivides into paleolithic, mesolithic & neolithic periods

(1, 3).clue: Krk Island, the northernmost island in the Mediterranean, lies in this arm of the sea next to the Balkans

(2, 3).clue: War & blood, blood & war / Hot Lips near cold corpses/ Comedy amidst pathos, thy name is Hawkeye

(3, 3).clue: 1957:This Frenchman who wrote "The First Man" & "The Plague"

(4, 3).clue: The term for those responsible for harnessing up the mules each morning lives on in the name of this labor union

(6, 3).clue: A trend-setting sports network with new hosts JC Chasez, Joey Fatone & Lance Bass

(1, 4).clue: This emirate NW of the United Arab Emirates is on a peninsula jutting 100 miles northward into the Persian Gulf

(2, 4).clue: Toby...sad sad sad sad Toby! / Your heart sang for Pam but Jim hath won the day / Yet move not to Costa Rica in shame!

(3, 4).clue: 1969:This playwright: did they keep him waiting?

(4, 4).clue: This board, established by the Wagner Act in 1935, allows workers to belong to the union of their choosing

(6, 4).clue: Bobby McFerrin song to a McDonald's kids' offering

(1, 5).clue: At the beginning of World War I, this was the only independent nation in West Africa

(2, 5).clue: Oh, Liz Lemon, persevere! / Though Tracy maketh films like "Honky Grandma Be trippin"' / Persevere!

(4, 5).clue: Chicago's Haymarket riot began during a rally for strikers at this agricultural equipment maker

(6, 5).clue: Fleegle & Bingo are about to unthinkingly make a controversial grammatical decision

(0, 0).clue: The first & middle names of this breakfast cereal "spokesman" are Horatio Magellan
